data.title: PublishCodeCoverageResults can't find its own html report when the agent is installed to a dir with a space in the name
data.body:
## Required Information

Entering this information will route you directly to the right team and expedite traction.

**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Bug

**Enter Task Name**:  PublishCodeCoverageResults@1

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines 
   

- Agent - Hosted or Private: 
    
        - Self hosted agent: vsts-agent-win-x64-2.168.2

    - Windows Server 2019 (1809)

## Issue Description

Task is configured to process a cobertura-coverage.xml produced by jest

```
        - task: PublishCodeCoverageResults@1
          inputs:
            codeCoverageTool: 'Cobertura'
            summaryFileLocation: './coverage/cobertura-coverage.xml'
            failIfCoverageEmpty: true
```
On execution, the task processes this and writes the report to a new (unexpected?) directory

```
Writing report file 'D:\Azure\index.htm'
```

This and other output files representing the source files are written correctly. 
The cobertura-coverage.xml is uploaded as an artifact.

However the task then states

```
Generated code coverage html report: D:\Azure Agent\vsts-agent-win-x64-2.168.2\_work\_temp\cchtml
```

and generates a warning

```
##[warning]Directory not found: 'D:\Azure Agent\vsts-agent-win-x64-2.168.2\_work\_temp\cchtml
```

There is nothing in that _temp directory.

If I specifically set reportDirectory to 'D:\Azure\' within the task it complains 

```
[warning]Ignoring coverage report directory with Html content as we are auto-generating Html content
```

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/devops/pipelines/tasks/test/publish-code-coverage-results?view=azure-devops doesn't document the reportDirectory option aside to say it's optional.

Have I come across a bug or is my configuration wrong?

Many thanks

data.title: Setting up static code scan
Docker Build and Push Command has flaky output (sometimes)
data.body:
## Required Information

**Bug**  
*Type*: Build fails. It shouldn't

**Enter Task Name**: Docker v2.170.2

## Environment
- Server: dev.azure.com
- Agent - Self hosted vsts container running in azure aks
- Image: microsoft/vsts-agent:ubuntu-16.04-docker-18.06.1-ce-standard
    
## Issue Description

We recently began receiving a rather meaningless error from a docker - build and push task. Somewhere in the dockerfile, around step 4 or 5, it starts doing node stuff, yarn install, yarn build etc. Theres no evidence in that output that the docker build process even began.

### Task logs
```
Starting: Build and Push Bullclip Web
==============================================================================
Task         : Docker
Description  : Build or push Docker images, login or logout, or run a Docker command
Version      : 2.170.2
Author       : Microsoft Corporation
Help         : https://aka.ms/azpipes-docker-tsg
==============================================================================
##[error]Unhandled: Failed find: ENOENT: no such file or directory, stat '/vsts/agent/_work/2/s/node_modules/@babel/plugin-proposal-async-generator-functions/node_modules/@babel/plugin-syntax-async-generators/node_modules/@babel/core/node_modules/.bin/json5'
Finishing: Build and Push Bullclip Web
```

I was able to build other pipelines with docker files (that nothing had nothing to do with node) at the time. I finally logged into the vsts container and ran `docker prune` (we still had 14gb of free space). After that the build began to work... I can't really confirm that that was the fix for it as I wasn't out of space.

Whatever the underlying problem was the output I got from the task was really baffling (still is) and is not actionable. If the error occurred in the docker build process i should see docker build output. If the docker environment was broken i should see an appropriate message. Instead I got a ENOENT seemingly in relation to some node operation.

There isn't even the `/usr/local/bin/docker build -f /vsts/agent/_work/3/s/Dockerfile ...` line.

data.title: Command-line task reports false success if STDIO left open
data.body:
_Originally posted by @glucaci in https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/issues/11334#issuecomment-583333300_

I've created new issue because nobody answers on closed one.
Below is the content of the original post:

### Original:
Lately we have the same problem with a .NET Core Task. I reported this also in https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-image-generation/issues/1386 because I'm not sure where this fits.
```
Starting: dotnet tool restore
==============================================================================
Task         : .NET Core
Description  : Build, test, package, or publish a dotnet application, or run a custom dotnet command
Version      : 2.164.0
Author       : Microsoft Corporation
Help         : https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/devops/pipelines/tasks/build/dotnet-core-cli
==============================================================================
/opt/hostedtoolcache/dotnet/dotnet tool restore --ignore-failed-sources --no-cache --verbosity normal

... restoring packages

Restore was successful.
The STDIO streams did not close within 10 seconds of the exit event from process '/opt/hostedtoolcache/dotnet/dotnet'. This may indicate a child process inherited the STDIO streams and has not yet exited.
```
and the task will remain blocked until build timeout expires.

### Update:
Also with Task Version 2.169.1

#### Workaround:
Enable ```Continue on error``` and set ```Timeout``` on 1 min

data.title: Allow ARM template deployment tasks to set ARM output variables as pipeline variables

labels.name: backlog
labels.description: Work that is on the backlog and won't get marked stale

data.body:
## Required Information

Entering this information will route you directly to the right team and expedite traction.

**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Feature

**Enter Task Name**: AzureResourceGroupDeploymentV2 and AzureResourceManagerTemplateDeploymentV3

https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/tree/master/Tasks/AzureResourceGroupDeploymentV2
https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/tree/master/Tasks/AzureResourceManagerTemplateDeploymentV3

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines

- Agent - Hosted

## Issue Description

As a pipeline yml author, I would like a simple way to make ARM template outputs available as pipeline variables.

Azure ARM deployment tasks do not provide the ability to unwrap template outputs and set them as pipeline variables. The readme for https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/tree/master/Tasks/AzureResourceManagerTemplateDeploymentV3 even offers a Powershell snippet for doing this.
```
$var=ConvertFrom-Json '$(storageAccountName)'
$value=$var.storageAccountName.value
Write-Host "##vso[task.setvariable variable=storageAccount;]$value"
```

It should not be necessary to add a separate script/pwsh/powershell step to unwrap the outputs section to make ARM outputs available as pipeline variables. Script snippets like this are easy to get wrong and difficult to get right across the various agent OSes and ARM output variable types.

I propose adding a boolean parameter to control the behaviour, such as `expandDeploymentOutputAsVariables: true`. When set to true, all output variables from the ARM template execution are set as pipeline variables, similar to if you included a script snippet like the above example.

### Task logs
n/a - feature request

## Troubleshooting
n/a - feature request

### Error logs
n/a - feature request

Can "Passed on rerun" and "Not Impacted" test statuses be set independently of VsTest task?
data.body:
**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Question

**Enter Task Name**: VsTest/PublishTestResults

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines or TFS on-premises?
    On-prem 16.131.27701.1

## Issue Description

We have complicated prerequisites for our unit tests. This prevents us from using the VsTest task (which is fine). We have built our own test distribution mechanism using Microsoft HPC. We would like to still keep track of which tests "passed on rerun" or were "not impacted" (we have this information, independent of the VsTest task). Can this be done by publishing a trx with a special unit test outcome? Or is there some other way we can manipulate the test results published to TFS?

As far as I can tell, the VsTest task uses TestSelector.exe to update the test results, which I'm assuming is where the passed-on-rerun/not-impacted data gets set. I don't know if TestSelector.exe is open-source, but I had trouble finding it.

data.title: Feature: Parallel artifact drops
data.body:
Presently, the [publish artifact task](https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/tree/master/Tasks/PublishPipelineArtifactV1) uses some function provided to the build agent to take a directory and publish it to some unknown place within Azure DevOps for use in a later pipeline.

I've performed some independent tests and found this to be remarkably slow for file transfers spanning many small files as it seems designed for only a few files to be moved. Per my test, I created a pipeline running on a self-hosted build agent that created 20,000 files all 100 kb in size, then performed two artifact drops.

One of these drops simply took the directory all these files were created in and published as-is to the drop endpoint. This took 22 minutes and 7 seconds despite each file transferring in only a few milliseconds because the logging indicates this is performed entirely as a sequential operation.

The other drop created a tar archive of everything first (no compression) and then uploaded only the single file to the drop. It took 2 minutes and 49 sec to create the archive and 1 minute 41 seconds to upload it, coming out to a total of 4 minutes and 30 seconds. Assuming the unarchiving takes around the same time to perform, the addition of this packaging step would come out to only 7 minutes and 19 seconds, taking only 33% of the time to execute as the existing approach.

Unfortunately, the linked task points to something for which I cannot find the source or I'd submit a pull request to improve on this. If someone can point me towards what I may have missed, I'd appreciate it and am happy to submit an improvement, but I'd otherwise ask that you consider adding this functionality to a future version.

I've attached the logs for the pipeline for your consideration.

Thank you.
[LogsAndTasks.zip](https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/files/4692371/LogsAndTasks.zip)

data.title: Allow to mark tests as flaky in PublishTestResults
data.body:
## Required Information

Entering this information will route you directly to the right team and expedite traction.

**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Feature

**Enter Task Name**: PublishTestResults

## Issue Description

According to https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/azure-devops-docs/issues/6700#issuecomment-575300329, a test can only be marked as flaky in a programmatic way by using the REST API. This is a huge barrier and likely only a few very dedicated souls will ever do that.

Instead of using the REST API it would be much simpler if PublishTestResults would optionally accept some kind of newline separated file containing a list of flaky test names.

data.title: Creating pipeline artifact of source folder silently fails
data.body:
## Required Information
**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Bug

**Enter Task Name**: PublishPipelineArtifact or DownloadPipelineArtifact

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines 

## Issue Description
`PublishPipelineArtifact@1` does not upload files from source folder. It seems that the deduplication step removes all files and nothing is uploaded?
Maybe because it is not changed from the previous build? But in that case: why does the download step not work?
Usecase: I want to publish arm templates from my source checkout in a **normal job**, so that I can consume them in a **deployment job**.

It sees the files, it simply does not upload them. I do not have any artifact exclusion / filter patterns. And, the download task seems not to be executed although it is there in my YAML pipeline.
Also, the download task that had to be injected automatically seems not to be injected.

data.title: AzureFunctionApp: Python remote build via requirements.txt
data.body:
## Required Information

Entering this information will route you directly to the right team and expedite traction.

**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Feature

**Enter Task Name**: AzureFunctionAppV1

list here (V# not needed):  
https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/tree/master/Tasks/AzureFunctionAppV1

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines 

- Agent - Hosted

## Issue Description

I'm trying to deploy a Python Function via AzureFunctionApp task. It is possible to deploy a Python Function via CLI and use the [remote build](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/azure-functions/functions-reference-python#remote-build) method. In this way, dependencies are obtained remotely based on the contents of the `requirements.txt` file. However, the AzureFunctionApp task [requires](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/azure-functions/functions-how-to-azure-devops?tabs=python#build-your-app) to install all the dependencies locally and zip them with the code when deploying. This is achieved via:

```bash
pip install --target="./.python_packages/lib/site-packages" -r ./requirements.txt
```

This way of deploying requires extra steps in the pipeline that do not add considerable value when we have simple PyPI dependencies. The task should allow to deploy just the definition of the dependencies in the `requirements.txt` file, without pip-installing them in a local target. This simple behaviour is already featured by the CLI:

```bash
func azure functionapp publish <APP_NAME>
```

data.body:
## Note  
Issues in this repo are for tracking bugs, feature requests and questions for the tasks in this repo 

For a list:  
https://github.com/Microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/tree/master/Tasks

If you have an issue or request for the Azure Pipelines service, use developer community instead:  

https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/spaces/21/index.html )

## Required Information

Entering this information will route you directly to the right team and expedite traction.

**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Question

**Enter Task Name**: Powershell V2.0

list here (V# not needed):  
https://github.com/Microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/tree/master/Tasks

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines or TFS on-premises?
Azure Pipelines
    
    - If using TFS on-premises, provide the version: 
    
    - If using Azure Pipelines, provide the account name, team project name, build definition name/build number: 

MSData / Vienna / MMS-Build


- Agent - Hosted or Private: 
    
    - If using Hosted agent, provide agent queue name: Azure Pipelines

    - If using private agent, provide the OS of the machine running the agent and the agent version: 

## Issue Description

Currently we use the Powershell task to scan modified files and add a tag to the build. This tag is then used to trigger Artifact-based tests for the associated PR.

This works great for including long-running tests that we don't want to run when non-impacted code has been touched.

What I would like to do is have a mechanism where if no tags are specified, then _all_ tests run. An easy way that I can think of to accomplish this would simply be to tag the build as 'UNKNOWN' if no other PR-related tags are present. However, I do not see a way to do this using the logging commands.

Currently we use:
       Write-Host "##vso[build.addbuildtag]$Tag"

I wanted to know if there's some way that we can retrieve the tags from within the build itself? I couldn't any documentation that answered this for me.

data.title: AzureCLI@V2: documentation should have examples
data.body:
## Note  
Issues in this repo are for tracking bugs, feature requests and questions for the tasks in this repo 

For a list:  
https://github.com/Microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/tree/master/Tasks

If you have an issue or request for the Azure Pipelines service, use developer community instead:  

https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/spaces/21/index.html )

## Required Information

Entering this information will route you directly to the right team and expedite traction.

**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Question

**Enter Task Name**: AzureCLI@V2

list here (V# not needed):  
https://github.com/Microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/tree/master/Tasks

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines or TFS on-premises?
    
    - If using TFS on-premises, provide the version: 
    
    - If using Azure Pipelines, provide the account name, team project name, build definition name/build number: 


- Agent - Hosted or Private: 
    
    - If using Hosted agent, provide agent queue name:

    - If using private agent, provide the OS of the machine running the agent and the agent version: 

## Issue Description

I am looking at the azurecli@v2 task and the documentation isn't comprehensive. it would be great to have actual examples of how different script locations are specified, how arguments are password etc. Also, the parameters section should really use the actual parameter that the task takes. For example, "Script Arguments": should really be written as "arguments" as that is the parameter that the actual yaml will recognize.

### Task logs

[Enable debug logging and please provide the zip file containing all the logs for a speedy resolution]

## Troubleshooting
Checkout how to troubleshoot failures and collect debug logs: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/vsts/build-release/actions/troubleshooting

### Error logs

[Insert error from the logs here for a quick overview]

data.title: Allow overriding existing files in ExtractFiles task.
data.body:
This change adds an optional input to override existing files when using the ExtractFiles task. The input will default to true as that is likely what the user wants. This will change the default behavior of the task.

[Related PR 1](https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/pull/6760)
[Related PR 2](https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/pull/11594)
[Related Issue 1](https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/issues/11082)
[Related Issue 2](https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/issues/11593)

data.title: Feature: Share cache across pipelines
data.body:
## Required Information

*Type*: Feature

**Enter Task Name**: Cache (https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/devops/pipelines/tasks/utility/cache?view=azure-devops / https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/tree/master/Tasks/CacheV2)

## Environment
- Azure Pipelines (yml)
- Can provide account / build / pipeline information privately
- Agent - Hosted vs2017-win2016

## Issue Description

I have a number of pipelines that run on the same hosted agent (around 50), for the same repository. All the pipelines use the same templates with lots of pipeline specific variables. I use the following cache task in a build template:

```
  - task: Cache@2
    condition: and(succeeded(), eq('${{ parameters.enableNugetCaching }}', true))
    displayName: NuGet Cache
    inputs:
      key: 'nuget | "${{ parameters.solution }}" | "$(Agent.OS)" | ${{ parameters.nugetConfig }},**/packages.config,!**/bin/**,!**/obj/**'
      restoreKeys: |
          nuget | "${{ parameters.solution }}" | "$(Agent.OS)"
          nuget | "${{ parameters.solution }}"
      path: '${{ parameters.nugetPackagesDirectorySource }}'
```

Caching works perfectly when I run a single pipeline twice - it restores the expected cache, and creates a new cache if one of the matched files changes, as you would expect.

However, when I run another pipeline on the same repo / set of code, the cache generates exactly the same key, but does not "match" against the existing cache - it generates a new one. As this cache is around 600mb in size, the "pipeline cache" for the Azure DevOps organisation is now around 30Gb when it should be 600mb. I would expect extra caches to only generate when the source input files change, and the old caches to expire after 30 days (would be handy for this to be customised too, but that's not as important). It also means that all 50 pipelines take around 2 mins extra each, eating into the pipeline minutes.

I've attached a screenshot of a compare between the two cache job runs in two separate pipelines. Everything except the X-TFS-Session identifier are exactly the same. Ideally, the cache key should be shared between pipelines that run on the same repo.

In addition, if I was able to share this cache between pipelines I would be able to reduce the build by another 2 or 3 mins as I could cache the main solution binaries too - which don't change that often. It's an odd scenario, but one which suits this particular client's build requirements perfectly.

I've also posted here:

https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/idea/1030422/share-cache-across-pipelines.html

### Task logs

[Cache log comparisons](https://pasteboard.co/J8j675B.png)

    - Agent Queue name: Azure Pipelines (https://dev.azure.com/markethype/MarketHype/_settings/agentqueues?queueId=17&view=jobs)

## Issue Description

Using the CacheV2 task to cache Yarn packages, we're getting an error in the post-job step of the cache task.

The task is defined exactly as in [the docs](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/devops/pipelines/release/caching?view=azure-devops#nodejsyarn).

```yaml
variables:
  YARN_CACHE_FOLDER: $(Pipeline.Workspace)/.yarn

steps:
- task: Cache@2
  inputs:
    key: 'yarn | "$(Agent.OS)" | yarn.lock'
    restoreKeys: |
       yarn | "$(Agent.OS)"
    path: $(YARN_CACHE_FOLDER)
  displayName: Cache Yarn packages
```

We're using the `vs2017-win2016` image.

### Error logs

data.body:

Azure Pipelines

## Issue Description

When you set an app setting, it (in my case) causes the app service to restart, however, the task completes at the beginning of the restart, causing the next task -- deploying the code package, to fail. data.title: Resync keys of Azure workspace returns error 504 Gateway Time-out
data.body:
I ran resync keys for my active directory Azure workspace. I followed the instructions given at the following links:

(using Try It) https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/rest/api/azureml/workspacesandcomputes/workspaces/resynckeys#code-try-0

and

(Using Azure Bash) https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/machine-learning/how-to-change-storage-access-key#code-try-2

But both the cases I got a response code "504 Gateway Time-out" (I have replaced the actual workspace name resource group name and sub id below for security purpose.)

Code:

ms@Azure:~$ az ml workspace sync-keys -w -g ProjectSystemException: Message: { "error_details": "\r\n504 Gateway Time-out\r\n\r\n

504 Gateway Time-out
\r\n


Can somebody tell what is going wrong here and how to proceed? (Note: I need to run resync keys to connect Azure devOps to Azure portal through service connection)

data.title: Publish artifact fails when retry failed job
data.body:
## Required Information

**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Bug

**Enter Task Name**: PublishPipelineArtifact
(and its `publish` yaml alias)

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines

    - account name, team project name, build definition name/build number: https://dev.azure.com/totodem/Test/_build?definitionId=13 (this is just a reproduction environment, it is not my actual pipeline)

- Agent - Any

## Issue Description

I have a 1st job that runs some tests and then publishes a report of what happened. Then I have a 2nd job that downloads this report to process it on some specific environment (it can't be done in the 1st job).

If tests fail at first and if I retry it and tests pass, then the job will still be failing because of the publish task saying that the artifact already exists for the run.

I really can't see any workaround in my scenario. Besides I think overwriting an existing artifact should be allowed (at least as an option if not as the default behavior).

## Issue Description
I have enabled the Code Coverage in the VS Test task
```
steps:
- task: VSTest@2
  displayName: 'Run unit tests'
  inputs:
    testAssemblyVer2: |
     **\*unittests*.dll
     !**\obj\**
    testFiltercriteria: '(TestCategory!=LocalOnly)&(TestCategory!=IntegrationTests)'
    runSettingsFile: test/TestRunSettings/local.runsettings
    codeCoverageEnabled: true
    platform: '$(BuildPlatform)'
    configuration: '$(BuildConfiguration)'
    publishRunAttachments: false
    diagnosticsEnabled: True
```

Once the build completes, I could see an option to download the code coverage report on the Code Coverage Tab of the build - 
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20378231/81420008-dab4d100-916c-11ea-9569-28cfed6ab1d6.png)
But the below section is empty.
I was wondering if it is possible to have the code coverage data visualized on the build itself in some tabular format ?

data.title: [UniversalPackages] Publish succeeds with 2 random guids

labels.name: aa-backlog
labels.description: Azure Artifacts tag for items under consideration in our backlog.

data.body:
## Required Information

Entering this information will route you directly to the right team and expedite traction.

**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Bug

**Enter Task Name**: UniversalPackages  


## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines
https://dev.azure.com/devopsmkb/Multivers/_build/results?buildId=19708&view=results  

- Agent - Hosted 
```
Pool: Azure Pipelines
Image: windows-latest
Agent: Hosted Agent
Started: Today at 10:12 AM
Duration: 2m 1s
```

## Issue Description

Using the following YAML:
```
- task: UniversalPackages@0
  condition: and(and(succeeded(), eq(variables['Build.SourceBranch'], 'refs/heads/master')), ne(variables.Build.Reason, 'PullRequest'))
  inputs:
    command: 'publish'
    publishDirectory: '$(Build.SourcesDirectory)\sme-resxsync\bin\Release'
    feedsToUsePublish: 'internal'
    vstsFeedPublish: '81dea1dd-cac5-4d61-81a3-b2e7ff0c64bf/7438584b-8726-4249-a331-a7b2745babe1'
    vstsFeedPackagePublish: 'sme-resxsync'
    versionOption: 'patch'
```

The Git repo with this pipeline was migrated from one account to another, the GUIDs above have no meaning in the new account. Project `81dea1dd-cac5-4d61-81a3-b2e7ff0c64bf` does not exist.
Feed `7438584b-8726-4249-a331-a7b2745babe1` does not exist.

I'd expect the build to fait on the missing target peed, but lo and behold:

The build succeeds without any issues and says it has published its packages somewhere. In the Project-level-feed with the name of the Project to be exact. The correct GUIDs for that feed are:

```
514f8a3e-5a1a-4502-b236-2c7abd5d0516/116c2548-4364-48b3-bf7b-70a619dd785
```

Expected outcome:

 * Build fails
 * No packages are published

Observed outcome:

 * Build succeeds
 * Packages are published to the wrong feed

### Task logs

```
Starting: UniversalPackages
==============================================================================
Task         : Universal packages
Description  : Download or publish Universal Packages
Version      : 0.168.0
Author       : Microsoft Corporation
Help         : https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/devops/pipelines/tasks
```

data.title: DownloadGitHubNugetPackageV1 fails to restore all NuGet packages, even though it shouldn't even be trying
data.body:
Entering this information will route you directly to the right team and expedite traction.

**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Bug

**Enter Task Name**: DownloadGitHubNugetPackageV1

list here (V# not needed):  
https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/tree/master/Tasks/DownloadGitHubNugetPackageV1

## Environment
- Server - [Azure Pipelines](https://dev.azure.com/yellowcounter/Swashbuckle.AspNetCore.SwaggerUI.Standalone/_build/results?buildId=673&view=results)

- Agent - Hosted:  windows-latest

## Issue Description

When downloading a GitHub Package, it fails to download packages from NuGet.org.

```yaml
- task: DownloadGitHubNugetPackage@1
  inputs:
    packageName: 'MisinformedDNA/MisinformedDNA.Swashbuckle.AspNetCore.AzureFunctions'
    version: '2.0.2-prerelease'
    externalFeedCredentials: GitHubPackages
```

results in 

> info : Adding PackageReference for package '***.Swashbuckle.AspNetCore.AzureFunctions' into project 'd:\a\1\Nuget\dotnet\tempCsproj_672.csproj'.
> warn : --no-restore|-n flag was used. No compatibility check will be done and the added package reference will be unconditional.
> info : PackageReference for package '***.Swashbuckle.AspNetCore.AzureFunctions' version '2.0.2-prerelease' added to file 'd:\a\1\Nuget\dotnet\tempCsproj_672.csproj'.
> "C:\Program Files\dotnet\dotnet.exe" restore d:\a\1\Nuget\dotnet\tempCsproj_672.csproj --configfile d:\a\1\Nuget\dotnet\nuget.config --no-cache --verbosity minimal
> d:\a\1\Nuget\dotnet\tempCsproj_672.csproj : warning NU1603: ***.Swashbuckle.AspNetCore.AzureFunctions 2.0.2-prerelease depends on Microsoft.AspNetCore.Mvc.Core (>= 2.1.3) but Microsoft.AspNetCore.Mvc.Core 2.1.3 was not found. An approximate best match of Microsoft.AspNetCore.Mvc.Core 2.2.0 was resolved.
> d:\a\1\Nuget\dotnet\tempCsproj_672.csproj : error NU1101: Unable to find package Microsoft.Azure.WebJobs.Extensions.Http. No packages exist with this id in source(s): github
> d:\a\1\Nuget\dotnet\tempCsproj_672.csproj : error NU1101: Unable to find package Swashbuckle.AspNetCore.Swagger. No packages exist with this id in source(s): github
> d:\a\1\Nuget\dotnet\tempCsproj_672.csproj : error NU1101: Unable to find package Swashbuckle.AspNetCore.SwaggerGen. No packages exist with this id in source(s): github
>   Restore failed in 22.69 sec for d:\a\1\Nuget\dotnet\tempCsproj_672.csproj.
> ##[error]Error: The process 'C:\Program Files\dotnet\dotnet.exe' failed with exit code 1
> ##[error]Package failed to restore
> 

So it says "--no-restore|-n flag was used", but then it appears to be trying a restore anyway, causing an error since the other packages are on nuget.org, not GitHub. Also, it says "No packages exist with this id in source(s): github", but I don't have a github source set up (at least in this latest attempt).

I've played around with NuGetAuthenticate, dotnet restore, nuget.config, etc, but I haven't been able to get anything to work.

Also note that the input `externalFeedCredentials` does not show up in the editor (but I determined that it needed to be a GitHub service connection):

data.title: Multiple checkout with custom paths fails in the container job
data.body:
## Required Information

*Type*: Bug

**Task Name**:  `checkout` aka `6d15af64-176c-496d-b583-fd2ae21d4df4@1`

## Environment

- Server - Azure Pipelines

  This is a private CI setup, I can provide the account name, team project name, build definition name/build number via email.

- Agent - Hosted, Azure Pipelines, `ubuntu-latest`

## Issue Description

When trying to use multiple checkout feature inside container job, it fails with `##[error]Unable to process command '##vso[plugininternal.updaterepositorypath alias=self;]/home/vsts/work/1/s' successfully.`

This `azure-pipelines.yml` reproduces the issue:

```yml
resources:
  containers:
  - container: netcore_sdk_3
    image: mcr.microsoft.com/dotnet/core/sdk:3.1
stages:
- stage:
  jobs:
  - job:
    container: netcore_sdk_3
    pool:
      vmImage: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - checkout: self
        path: s
      - checkout: self
        path: s/.azd
```

### Task logs

Anonymized task logs: [azd_logs.zip](https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/files/4595659/azd_logs.zip)

data.title: AzureCLIV2 allow hiding 'az login' output
data.body:
Currently when we use the AzureCLI v2 task it is doing automatically for us the `az login` command. This command returns an array of all the subscription the logged in user has access to.

Our service principal has access to hundreds of subscriptions and this is polluting our logs as we get almost 5000 lines of logs just for this output.

It would be great to have a parameter to disable `az login` output; if this parameter is set then when calling `az login` the parameter `-o none` would be added.

data.title: Parameter for choosing the version of SqlPackage.exe
data.body:
*Type*: Feature

**Enter Task Name**:  SqlDacpacDeploymentOnMachineGroupV0 

## Issue Description
There should be a way to specify which version of SqlPackage.exe should be used. Always using the latest version installed on the Agent does not work.

### Error logs
I was getting this error:
`*** Error parsing connection string: The type initializer for 'Microsoft.SqlServer.Dac.DacProfile' threw an exception..`

On investigating further, the solution was the SqlPackage.exe from version 110 should have been used instead of the latest version on the Agent (which was 120)

data.title: PublishSymbolsV2 does not index PDBs embedded inside PE files
data.body:
## Note  
Issues in this repo are for tracking bugs, feature requests and questions for the tasks in this repo 

For a list:  
https://github.com/Microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/tree/master/Tasks

If you have an issue or request for the Azure Pipelines service, use developer community instead:  

https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/spaces/21/index.html )

## Required Information

Entering this information will route you directly to the right team and expedite traction.

**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Bug

**Enter Task Name**: PublishSymbolsV2

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines (all accounts)
- Agent - Hosted (all queues)

## Issue Description

The C# compiler supports [embedding the PDB inside the PE file](https://github.com/dotnet/roslyn/issues/12390). When this happens, the .pdb file is not present on disk and the PublishSymbolsV2 task doesn't pick it up. Therefore tools looking for the pdb in symbol servers don't find it and fail to perform their task.

### Task logs

N/A

N/A

N/A

data.title: MSBuild task falls back to older version when specific msbuild version selected (other than latest)
data.body:

**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Bug

**Enter Task Name**: MSBuild

https://github.com/Microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/tree/master/Tasks

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines
   
    - If using Azure Pipelines, provide the account name, team project name, build definition name/build number: 
Microsoft Corp, Minecraft, GH_MB_Win64_Public_Server, buildId=4069884
This applies to all of our pipelines that specify MSBuild 16.0 or 15.0

- Agent - Hosted 
    
    - If using Hosted agent, provide agent queue name: 

Minecraft Win32 Build Pool
Windows (Windows Server 2016 Datacenter)
Standard DS4 v2 (8 vcpus, 28 GiB memory)

## Issue Description

The hosted machines all have VS2019, VS2017 and msbuild 14.0. Some of the agents appear to become corrupt, in that Invoke-VstsTool encounters unexpected errors and returns an error code. 

##[debug]Error 0x80070583: Class does not exist.

Our GH_MB_Win64_Public_Server pipeline specified MSBuild Version 15.0, and when the Agent is in this error state with Invoke-VstsTool, this causes msbuild 15.0 to not be found. Because, Latest was not specified, this should result in an error and the task should fail. Instead, a verbose-logging statement logs that fallback will be attempted, and fallback logic is used AS-IF 'latest' was specified.

PathFunctions.ps1, Line 285: Write-Verbose "Specified version '$PreferredVersion' and architecture '$Architecture' not found. Attempting to fallback."

Because a specific version of msbuild was specified and that version was not found, the task should error out. Line 285 uses verbose logging when a specified version cannot be found, instead this line should read the same as Line 302 which generates an error.

PathFunctions.ps1, Line 302: Write-Error (Get-VstsLocString -Key 'MSB_MSBuildNotFoundVersion0Architecture1' -ArgumentList $PreferredVersion, $Architecture)

data.title: Feature Request: Add ConfiguratioName parameter to PowerShell on Target Machines task
data.body:
## Required Information

Entering this information will route you directly to the right team and expedite traction.

**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Feature

**Enter Task Name**: PowerShell on Target Machines task

## Issue Description

I would like to request ability to specify which PowerShell Configuration will be used while using PowerShell on Target Machines task.

Currently while using PowerShell on Target Machines task, version 3.x user cannot specify what Configuration PSSession will be used.
If there is requirement to use specific configuration while running code, user has to write hes own PowerShell code, and using standard PowerShell task.

Using [configurations ](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/microsoft.powershell.core/about/about_session_configuration_files?view=powershell-5.1 )with PowerShell Remote Sessions can increase security while combining it with [JEA](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/scripting/learn/remoting/jea/session-configurations?view=powershell-5.1) and address [double hop issue](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/scripting/learn/remoting/ps-remoting-second-hop?view=powershell-5.1) in applications (i.e SharePoint On-Premise).

Currently, as we can see in [code](https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/blob/1d75fa8f66aa1cf7a9cb62946939f30f087b2969/Tasks/PowerShellOnTargetMachinesV3/PowerShellOnTargetMachines.ps1), remote session is created using default Powershell configuration `microsoft.powershell`, but apparently script was designed to support using custom configurations in the future:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/41610384/80701052-0ede2100-8adf-11ea-807a-4d6f3b8b6731.png)

data.title: Correct the description of the BuildNumber Output Variable
data.body:
**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Bug

**Enter Task Name**: DownloadBuildArtifacts

https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/commits/master/Tasks/DownloadBuildArtifactsV0

## Issue Description

The Output Variable called BuildNumber does not contain the BuildNumber, but the BuildId. Requests to change the name from BuildNumber to BuildId have been denied in the past with regards to backward compatibility.
However, at least the description should be corrected. The description should state that the variable contains the build id and contrary to its name does not contain the build number.
The same applies to the DownloadPipelineArtifact task.

data.title: Add Output Variable ArtifactBuildNumber
data.body:
**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Feature

**Enter Task Name**: DownloadBuildArtifacts

https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/commits/master/Tasks/DownloadBuildArtifactsV0

## Issue Description

There is already an Output Variable called BuildNumber. Unfortunately it does not contain the BuildNumber, but the BuildId. Requests to change the name from BuildNumber to BuildId have been denied in the past with regards to backward compatibility.
Hence, there should be a new Output Variable that contains the real BuildNumber.
The same applies to the DownloadPipelineArtifact task.

data.title: Azure Powershell Task v.4.168.0 affect Enable-ContextAutoSave
data.body:
## Required Information

Entering this information will route you directly to the right team and expedite traction.

**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Question

**Enter Task Name**: Azure Powershell  

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines
    
- Agent - Hosted

## Issue Description

In my script I have an Enable-AzContextAutoSave which always work fine. But recently all my new releases and redeployed releases (which succeeded before) were failed. My pipeline configurations were all the same, the script hasn't been touched, I just trigger the pipeline.
I did some investigation and found out that Get-AzContext in my script returned null, including every command that is using the context (e.g. Get-AzSubscription return error message said I have to run Connect-AzAccount).
After a while I realized that the tasks version have just changed from 4.167.0 to 4.168.0 and then the one that failed all my release is the Enable-AzContextAutoSave command.

So I had a look in your repo and found this:
https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/commit/e4127e0977a9fd22caf09a53b627bb1263765ba7

**Should there be any notice to the users before rolling out this change??** I understand that this might be a minor change, but it could affect users. I have to spent some times to find the cause of this out-of-nowhere issue and it affected my deployment timeline.

data.title: Fixed two issues in docs/pinToTaskVersion/pinToTaskVersion.md
data.body:
Fixed incorrect path value assignment to $taskDir (as build results are located in _build\Tasks\<task-name>, not Tasks\<task-name>), which causes an unusable task to be installed in the TFS app-tier, as the .js-files are missing and thus also missing when being downloaded by an agent.

Added missing backslash after dot in call to New-TaskInstallScript.ps1.

data.title: NPM Publish permission denied failure
data.body:
## Required Information

Entering this information will route you directly to the right team and expedite traction.

**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Question

**Enter Task Name**: Npm

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines

- Agent - Hosted: ubuntu-latest

## Issue Description
Trying to perform an npm publish, i am getting permission denied errors from the scripts that need to run in the package.json file. I can't find the page that mentioned it, but I remember reading that npm commands should be executed with sudo. Is there a way that I can execute this task with sudo privileges?

Task yaml:

```
- task: Npm@1
  displayName: Publish TypeScript SDK
  inputs:
``` 

data.title: SqlAzureDacpacDeployment@1 does not support ampersand in password
data.body:
**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Bug

SqlAzureDacpacDeployment@1 does not support certain characters in password when using `authenticationType: aadAuthenticationPassword`

## Environment
- Azure Pipelines

- Agent - Hosted 

## Issue Description

I spent 2 days trying to figure out why **SqlAzureDacpacDeployment** did not work, whereas using Invoke-Sqlcmd with the same parameters succeeded.
Troubleshooting of SqlAzureDacpacDeployment is very limited, since most of the time AggregateException is thrown, so error message says only 

> ##[error]One or more errors occurred.Check out how to troubleshoot failures at https://aka.ms/sqlazuredeployreadme#troubleshooting-

In the end it turned out that the **task does not support** certain character in password: **&**

I did try:
- wrapping login/password parameters with double quotes:

```
    - task: AzureKeyVault@1
            displayName: 'Import Key Vault secrets'
            inputs:
              azureSubscription: "Azure Sub"
              KeyVaultName: 'vault-deployment-tst'
              SecretsFilter: 'DbDeployAdminName, DbDeployAdminPassword'

    - task: SqlAzureDacpacDeployment@1
            displayName: 'Upgrade DB'
            inputs:
              azureSubscription: 'Azure Sub'
              authenticationType: aadAuthenticationPassword
              aadSqlUsername: "$(DbDeployAdminName)"
              aadSqlPassword: "$(DbDeployAdminPassword)"
              serverName: 'tst-sql01.database.windows.net'
              databaseName: 'TheDB-tst'
              deployType: sqlTask
              sqlFile: '$(Pipeline.Workspace)/s/deploy/sql/DB.sql'

```
- wrapping login/password parameters with single quotes:

```
    - task: AzureKeyVault@1
            displayName: 'Import Key Vault secrets'
            inputs:
              azureSubscription: "Azure Sub"
              KeyVaultName: 'vault-deployment-tst'
              SecretsFilter: 'DbDeployAdminName, DbDeployAdminPassword'

    - task: SqlAzureDacpacDeployment@1
            displayName: 'Upgrade DB'
            inputs:
              azureSubscription: 'Azure Sub'
              authenticationType: aadAuthenticationPassword
              aadSqlUsername: '$(DbDeployAdminName)'
              aadSqlPassword: '$(DbDeployAdminPassword)'
              serverName: 'tst-sql01.database.windows.net'
              databaseName: 'TheDB-tst'
              deployType: sqlTask
              sqlFile: '$(Pipeline.Workspace)/s/deploy/sql/DB.sql'

```

- not wrapping login/password parameters at all:

```
    - task: AzureKeyVault@1
            displayName: 'Import Key Vault secrets'
            inputs:
              azureSubscription: "Azure Sub"
              KeyVaultName: 'vault-deployment-tst'
              SecretsFilter: 'DbDeployAdminName, DbDeployAdminPassword'

    - task: SqlAzureDacpacDeployment@1
            displayName: 'Upgrade DB'
            inputs:
              azureSubscription: 'Azure Sub'
              authenticationType: aadAuthenticationPassword
              aadSqlUsername: $(DbDeployAdminName)
              aadSqlPassword: $(DbDeployAdminPassword)
              serverName: 'tst-sql01.database.windows.net'
              databaseName: 'TheDB-tst'
              deployType: sqlTask
              sqlFile: '$(Pipeline.Workspace)/s/deploy/sql/DB.sql'

```
- even reading information available by the link https://aka.ms/sqlazuredeployreadme#troubleshooting-

No additional information is available in diagnostics mode since credentials are masked:
`-sqlUserName *** -sqlPassword *** `

If this cannot be fixed easily, please add information about the limitation at https://aka.ms/sqlazuredeployreadme#troubleshooting-

I also think that handling **AggregateException** would help a lot

![Annotation 2020-04-23 195239](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4918115/80132937-bc5faa80-859c-11ea-9e8c-2b159f164f95.png)

data.title: UseDotNetV2 fetches the releases JSON even if an explicit SDK version is requested that is cached locally
data.body:
The UseDotNetV2 task currently fetches the [releases-index.json](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/dotnet/core/master/release-notes/releases-index.json) every time it runs to check if it needs to download a new version. This is fine if you have a version specification that requires this check.

However, when you have a specific fixed version, e.g. `3.1.201`, the task shouldnt have to download the index file to eventually see that the requested version is already cached locally by the build agent. So it doesnt need to check the index file because it neither needs to resolve a version, nor does it need a download URL.

This would be very helpful especially in situations where GitHub is having issues (which was the case a few minutes ago) and downloading the index file fails. If the agent would just skip the download and use the cached version directly, then builds could just continue to work.

### Required Information
**Type**: Feature
**Enter Task Name**: UseDotNetV2
**Environment**: All environments, but in particular on premise with an on-premise build agent that allows caching the SDK.

data.title: NuGet - getaddrinfo EAI_AGAIN dev.azure.com:443
data.body:
## Note  
Issues in this repo are for tracking bugs, feature requests and questions for the tasks in this repo 

For a list:  
https://github.com/Microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/tree/master/Tasks

If you have an issue or request for the Azure Pipelines service, use developer community instead:  

https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/spaces/21/index.html )

## Required Information

Entering this information will route you directly to the right team and expedite traction.

**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Bug

**Enter Task Name**: NuGetToolInstaller / NuGetCommand

list here (V# not needed):  
https://github.com/Microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/tree/master/Tasks

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines or TFS on-premises?
    
   Azure Pipelines :
  - Account name : nventive
  - Team project id : d2616ba2-efcb-4425-9794-a729f983658b
  - Build definition id : 1173
  - Build id : 166702

- Agent - Hosted or Private: 
    
  Private agent:
  - Windows 10.0.17763
  - 6 agents running with version 2.165.0

## Issue Description

When running builds with the NuGet tool installer and the NuGet command tasks, we're intermittently running into `getaddrinfo EAI_AGAIN dev.azure.com:443` errors in either of those tasks: if the NuGet tool is not found on the machine, it'll fail and it's already installed on the machine, the command task will fail.

We haven't noticed a potential source for this problem on our side, it just seems to happen randomly. Once one agent has started experiencing that, most of the NuGet tasks launched on any agents running on this host will fail (not 100% sure of that, it seems that some NuGet commands still work).

So far, all the builds that have experienced this issue were running using [container jobs](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/devops/pipelines/process/container-phases?view=azure-devops) with [a custom Windows-based image](https://hub.docker.com/r/nventive/build-agent)

The only way we've found to fix that was to reboot the machine running the agents.

data.title: When using Azure DevOps CI/CD for a Linux web app how can I zip and publish the build artifact as a zip file only instead of copying to directory
data.body:
[Per these instructions][1] I am creating devops project integrating CI/CD for a Linux Web App. 

Here is my initial Pipelines pipelines/build job

```yaml
trigger:
- master

pool:
  vmImage: 'ubuntu-latest'

steps:
- task: NodeTool@0
  inputs:
    versionSpec: '12.x'
  displayName: 'Install Node.js'

- script: |
    npm install -g @angular/cli
    npm install
    npm run build:ssr
  displayName: 'npm install and build'

- task: CopyFiles@2
  inputs:
    Contents: |
      dist/** 
      node_modules/**
      package.json
    TargetFolder: '$(Build.ArtifactStagingDirectory)'
    CleanTargetFolder: true
    OverWrite: true

- task: PublishBuildArtifacts@1
  inputs:
    PathtoPublish: '$(Build.ArtifactStagingDirectory)'
    ArtifactName: 'drop'
    publishLocation: 'Container'

```
When because the `CopyFiles@2` task there are 65000 files copying over to the directory to be published in the following `PublishBuildArtifacts@1` task.  

Because of this I thought I could add the `Artifact` task after the copy task and this would produce a `.zip` file and make the deployment more efficient and many times over faster.  

However, this was not the case and all it did was serve to zip the folder up, un-zip the folder and proceed to do the same individual file processing like show below. At the time it took me to write this post it has been about 14 minutes and this is how far it has gotten.

data.body:
## Required Information
*Type*: bug 
**Enter Task Name**: DotNetCoreCLIV2 (v2.131.0)

## Environment
- Server -  TFS on-premises 2018.U2
- Agent - Private: 
  - Agent.OS | Windows_NT (Server 2012R2)

  - Agent.Version | 2.131.0

Using `Destination directory` aka `--packages` cmdline option break user Nuget.config loading.

data.title: [BUG] Glob pattern in cURL task
data.body:
**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Bug

**Enter Task Name**: cURL upload files

## Issue Description

I'm using list pattern for my files in cURL task.
The task interprets fine the pattern, but it define the root path totally wrong with the curly braces.

https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/blob/469f022c8afa18a9035a3a70f4086a35779cb436/Tasks/CUrlUploaderV2/curluploader.ts#L85

data.title: Download pipeline artifact breaks folder structure when downloading pipeline artifact
data.body:
## Required Information

Entering this information will route you directly to the right team and expedite traction.

**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Bug

**Enter Task Name**:  DownloadPipelineArtifact@2  

list here (V# not needed):  
https://github.com/Microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/tree/master/Tasks

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines

- Agent - Private Windows agent, agent version 2.165.0

## Issue Description

If you are downloading a pipeline artifact (from another pipeline) and the name of the artifact is used in the folder structure of the artifact, it can cause the following issues.

Folder level removed, file renamed:

Solutions/ThisIsAnArtifactName/url.runsettings
-> Solutions/ThisIsAnurl.runsettings

Folder level removed:
Solutions/ThisIsAnArtifactName/Obj/...
-> Solutions/ThisIsAnObj/...

So it seems that the 'artifact name' is deleted from the folder structure, which may result in lost folder-levels or changed folder names and changed file names. And the breaking only happens for only the folder that has similarities with the artifact name, rest of the folders stay as they should. Also if you check the built artifact, there the folder structure is correct. So the copying breaks it.

### Task logs

No logs, just observed functionality from the result.

## Troubleshooting
Checkout how to troubleshoot failures and collect debug logs: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/vsts/build-release/actions/troubleshooting

### Error logs

No logs, just observed functionality from the result.

data.title: Unable to set secure file to download based on pipeline variables
data.body:
## Required Information

- **Type**: Bug
- **Task Name**: DownloadSecureFile  

## Environment

- **Server**: Azure Pipelines
- **Agent**: Hosted

## Issue Description

We'd like to store credentials for different environments in different secure files. For example, we might have:

- `creds-a.env`
- `creds-b.env`
- `creds-c.env`

Based on the context of the current YAML pipeline, we can determine whether we're deploying to `a`, `b`, or `c`. It's important to note that we don't have this at the very start of the pipeline and it's not something we can hardcode or ask for; it's a runtime evaluation.

I'll put some pseudocode here, but the pipeline looks sort of like:

```yaml
- task: Bash@3
  inputs:
    targetType: inline
    script: |
      # Figure out the target environment, then write a variable for later use.
      echo "##vso[task.setvariable variable=target;]a"
- task: DownloadSecureFile@1
   name: credentials
   inputs:
     secureFile: creds-$(target).env
```

Unfortunately, it [appears `DownloadSecureFile` runs before the job](https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/blob/91ed11388bfa1462fd999a7849c3c8b5db08eccb/Tasks/DownloadSecureFileV1/task.json#L50) which means we can't affect the filename by running analysis in the pipeline like this.

It's not obvious that a job placed explicitly at a particular location in the pipeline is going to try to do work before the point at which it appears; and it seems like a defect that we're unable to use secure files in a more flexible way.

data.title: Question: regarding artifacts reuse across multiple stages
data.body:
Hey Guys, 
I have a question regarding artifacts across multiple stage. 
Please see my pseudo pipeline code bellow. 

- I am using artifacts that are defined under resources.
- In stage DeployToUAT, it will be downloaded automatically (since it's deloyment job).
- Let's say DeployToProd  will be executed after a week due to approval process.
- Which version of Release pipeline,  DeployToProd  will download? then same one as it as was downloaded in first stage DeployToUAT or the latest version that exist on the time of run.  
- Both stages are executed on different self-hosted agents 

```
resources:
  pipelines:
    - pipeline: Release
      source: Release_CI

stages:
  - stage: DeployToUAT
    jobs:  
    - deployment: deployObjects
      pool:
        name: 'lab'
        demands: 
          - Agent.Name -equals UATAgent
      workspace:
        clean: all
      environment:
        name: UAT
      strategy:
        runOnce:
          deploy:
            steps:
            - checkout: self
              clean: true  
            - template: deploymentStepsTemplate.yml
              parameters:
                instanceName: 'UAT'

- stage: DeployToProd    
    jobs:               
      - deployment: deployObjects
        pool:
          name: 'prod'
          demands: 
            - Agent.Name -equals ProdAgent
        environment:
          name: Prod
        strategy:
          runOnce:
            deploy:
              steps:
              - checkout: self
                clean: true  
              - template: deploymentStepsTemplate.yml
                parameters:
                  instanceName: 'PROD'
                  deployFob: $(deployFob)
```

data.title: Zero lines covered in Cobertura yields confusing error messaage
data.body:
## Required Information

- **Type**: Bug
- **Task Name**: `PublishCodeCoverageResults`

## Environment

- Server - Azure Pipelines
- Agent - Hosted / Ubuntu

## Issue Description

I'm setting up a build for a brand new .NET Core project. There are skeleton projects in there that have not been totally filled out yet, but it's enough to compile and run Hello World. As part of that, I'm setting up coverage reporting using Coverlet and Cobertura output.

When I run tests with coverage, I do get a valid XML coverage report coming out. I then run that through [the report generator extension](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=Palmmedia.reportgenerator) and, finally, use the aggregated report to `PublishCodeCoverageResults`.

However, while there _is a report_ there is not currently any actual _line coverage_ because the tests aren't quite there yet. This yields a very confusing error message withe a debug log like this:

```text
##[debug]findPath: '/home/vsts/work/1/a/log/coverage/Cobertura.xml'
##[debug]statOnly: 'true'
##[debug]found 1 paths
##[debug]applying include pattern
##[debug]1 matches
##[debug]1 final results
##[debug]Found 1 result(s) matching pattern: /home/vsts/work/1/a/log/coverage/Cobertura.xml
##[debug]Resolved summary file: /home/vsts/work/1/a/log/coverage/Cobertura.xml
##[debug]Reading XML file: /home/vsts/work/1/a/log/coverage/Cobertura.xml
##[debug]Converting XML file to JSON
##[debug]task result: Failed
##[error]No code coverage results were found to publish.
```

There _are coverage results_ and they _could be published_ but it's saying nothing was found.

The error is [here](https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/blob/5d99f827ece0b04fb09f7b290a00e7fc64102f7a/Tasks/Common/codecoverage-tools/codecoverageutilities.ts#L16):

```typescript
else if (codeCoverageTool.toLowerCase() === 'cobertura' && resp.coverage) {
  let lines_covered: number = Number(resp.coverage.$["lines-covered"]);
  if (lines_covered && lines_covered > 0) {
    return Q.resolve(false);
  }
}
```

Basically, it says if there are zero lines covered, return that there was no coverage found. Way up the stack, that yields a very generic "no results" message. The message shown in the logs says that there weren't _any_ results; not that the results showed no coverage.

While this seems like a minor semantic issue, I honestly just sank like a day into debugging deep into the task trying to figure out whether there was a problem with the report format, or the report generator plugin, or whether maybe the `xml2js` module couldn't read the file, or something else. It might be good to have a debug message in there to say something about how there _are results_ it's just that there's nothing of value to report. It'd have saved a lot of time.

data.title: The "File Transformation Task" needs to be renamed to include "And Pipeline Variable Substitution"
data.body:
I just spent several hours of time trying to figure out how the resulting deployed web.config file for an application is getting a value for a connection string that is not specified in the web.config, the web.<thatenvironment>.config, or any other file in the project. 

It was only after copying the build definition json to a text editor and searching did I find that there was a pipeline variable that was the potential source, but it took a while longer (more reading) to realize that while the "File Transformation Task" does perform that intended service, it does something else - replaces content in those files with pipeline variables. 

* The naming for the task is misleading in one of the worst ways - an unrelated or nonsense name that does not describe the functionality of the task would be a safer choice than the one it has now that very specifically describes only half of the total functionality (and you cant even opt out of the unsaid half)
* The documentation is slightly misleading as it does not mention that the variables its discussing are pipeline variables until a teeny little blue "Note" after the examples.  
* The log messages that are emitted reinforce that like its name implies, this task is yet another XDT task. It doesnt state what variables its using or what values, or that its even using pipeline variables and not environment or other variables.

data.title: Feature Request - AzureAppServiceSettingsV1 - Wait for restart
data.body:
## Required Information
**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Feature

**Enter Task Name**: AzureAppServiceSettingsV1

## Environment
Azure Pipelines
Agent Hosted
    
## Issue Description

This is a feature request for task AzureAppServiceSettingsV1 team
@Vijay-train @chshrikh  @eaarora-ms @SumiranAgg

For most Azure App Services, updating the configuration will require an application restart. 
The default behavior of the AzureAppServiceSettingsV1 task doesn't wait for that restart to complete before finishing.
Can we add an **option to delay completion of this task until the App Service has restarted**?

I understand some folks may want a "fire and forget" behavior, may I recommend a "wait for app service restart" toggle box?   Or perhaps make the default behavior to wait and supply "continue immediately" toggle box? Thoughts?

Adjusting the behavior would be beneficial to teams that perform integration tests inside the pipeline, such as this ... 

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1102958/78168081-62e0e180-741d-11ea-9c13-d2d04d8172b5.png)

Above, our newman postman tests fail because the application hasn't finished restarting. 
I am **willing to make a PR on this** feature if it helps!   Thanks.

- Troy Witthoeft
